metadata.title: Multiscaling in multifractals  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
metadata.text: Multiscaling is shown to be a consequence of multifractality when a lower cutoff ɛ is introduced in calculations of correlation functions. After a suitable rescaling, the correlation function data for different values of ɛ seem to fall onto a single curve. In the multiscaling regime, however, we show that there is not a unique functional form at varying ɛ, but a spread very close to a single curve. For each ɛ, this curve can be computed analytically in terms of the f(α) spectrum which characterizes the multifractal. Part of this spectrum can thus be obtained by computing only one moment of the weights at ɛ≠0.

metadata.title: Multiscaling in multifractals  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
metadata.text: Multiscaling is shown to be a consequence of multifractality when a lower cutoff ɛ is introduced in calculations of correlation functions. After a suitable rescaling, the correlation function data for different values of ɛ seem to fall onto a single curve. In the multiscaling regime, however, we show that there is not a unique functional form at varying ɛ, but a spread very close to a single curve. For each ɛ, this curve can be computed analytically in terms of the f(α) spectrum which characterizes the multifractal. Part of this spectrum can thus be obtained by computing only one moment of the weights at ɛ≠0.

metadata.title: Intermittency in fully developed turbulence: Log-Poisson statistics and generalized scale covariance  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
metadata.text: Some properties of a model of intermittency in fully developed turbulence due to She and Lévêque [Phys. Rev. Lett. 72, 336 (1994)] are explored. The probability functions solution of the model is shown to be simply related to the log- Poisson statistics of local nondimensional energy dissipation. It is also shown that the intermittency obtained by She and Lévêque can be interpreted as the consequence of the scale covariance of the energy dissipation. Based on these observations, a new picture of turbulence is presented, in which scale covariance plays a central role.

metadata.title: Multifractal wave functions at the Anderson transition  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
metadata.text: Electronic wave functions in disordered systems are studied within the Anderson model of localization. At the critical disorder in 3D we diagonalize very large (103 823×103 823) secular matrices by means of the Lanczos algorithm. On all length scales the obtained strong spatial fluctuations of the amplitude of the eigenstates display a multifractal character, reflected in the set of generalized fractal dimensions and the singularity spectrum of the fractal measure. An analysis of 1D systems shows multifractality too, in contrast to previous claims.

metadata.title: Anderson transitions  |  Rev. Mod. Phys.
metadata.text: The physics of Anderson transitions between localized and metallic phases in disordered systems is reviewed. The term “Anderson transition” is understood in a broad sense, including both metal-insulator transitions and quantum-Hall-type transitions between phases with localized states. The emphasis is put on recent developments, which include multifractality of critical wave functions, criticality in the power-law random banded matrix model, symmetry classification of disordered electronic systems, mechanisms of criticality in quasi-one- dimensional and two-dimensional systems and survey of corresponding critical theories, network models, and random Dirac Hamiltonians. metadata.title: Multifractality in human heartbeat dynamics - PubMed
metadata.text: There is evidence that physiological signals under healthy conditions may have a fractal temporal structure. Here we investigate the possibility that time series generated by certain physiological control systems may be members of a special class of complex processes, termed multifractal, which require a large number of exponents to characterize their scaling properties. We report on evidence for multifractality in a biological dynamical system, the healthy human heartbeat, and show that the multifractal character and nonlinear properties of the healthy heart rate are encoded in the Fourier phases. We uncover a loss of multifractality for a life-threatening condition, congestive heart failure.

metadata.title: Multifractal random walk  |  Phys. Rev. E
metadata.text: We introduce a class of multifractal processes, referred to as multifractal random walks (MRWs). To our knowledge, it is the first multifractal process with continuous dilation invariance properties and stationary increments. MRWs are very attractive alternative processes to classical cascadelike multifractal models since they do not involve any particular scale ratio. The MRWs are indexed by four parameters that are shown to control in a very direct way the multifractal spectrum and the correlation structure of the increments. We briefly explain how, in the same way, one can build stationary multifractal processes or positive random measures.

metadata.text: position of the maximum α _{0} where f(α) reaches its maxima; width of the spectrum W = α max − α min which can be obtained from extrapolating the fitted f(α) curve to zero; and skew shape of the spectrum r = (α max − α _{0})/(α _{0} − α min). In a nutshell, large value of α _{0} means the underlying process is more irregular. The wider the spectrum (larger W), the richer the structure of the time series. The skew parameter r determines which fractal exponents are dominant. Right skew shape of the spectrum with r > 1 is more complex than left skew shape with r < 1 [31 ,  50].

We focus upon the scaling properties of such measures, by considering their singularities, which are characterized by two indices: α, which determines the strength of their singularities; and f, which describes how densely they are distributed. The spectrum of singularities is described by giving the possible range of α values and the function f(α). metadata.title: Direct determination of the f(\ensuremath{\alpha}) singularity spectrum and its application to fully developed turbulence  |  Phys. Rev. A
metadata.text: This paper focuses on a method proposed for determining f(α) (the singularity spectrum of a multifractal) directly from experimental data, without first calculating the ‘‘generalized dimensions’’  and applying the usual Legendre transforms. We describe the method, which is based on theorems by Shannon, Eggelston, and Billingsley, and apply it to one-dimensional cuts of the dissipation field of fully developed turbulence in laboratory and atmospheric flows. The accuracy of this method can be understood in terms of computation of conventional thermodynamic quantities in microcanonical and canonical ensembles.

metadata.title: Direct determination of the f(\ensuremath{\alpha}) singularity spectrum  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
metadata.text: The direct determination of the f(α) singularity spectrum from experimental data is a difficult problem. This Letter introduces a simple method for computing f(α) based on the theorems of Shannon, Eggelston, and Billingsley which is markedly superior to other recently proposed methods, especially when dealing with experimental data from low-dimensional chaotic systems where the underlying dynamics are unknown.

metadata.title: [physics/0202070] Multifractal detrended fluctuation analysis of nonstationary time series
metadata.text: > Abstract: We develop a method for the multifractal characterization of nonstationary time series, which is based on a generalization of the detrended fluctuation analysis (DFA). We relate our multifractal DFA method to the standard partition function-based multifractal formalism, and prove that both approaches are equivalent for stationary signals with compact support. By analyzing several examples we show that the new method can reliably determine the multifractal scaling behavior of time series. By comparing the multifractal DFA results for original series to those for shuffled series we can distinguish multifractality due to long-range correlations from multifractality due to a broad probability density function. metadata.title: Wavelets and multifractal formalism for singular signals: Application to turbulence data  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
metadata.text: The wavelet decomposition is used to generalize the multifractal formalism to singular signals. The singularity spectrum is directly determined from the scaling behavior of partition functions that are defined from the wavelet transform modulus maxima. Illustrations on fractal signals with a recursive structure, e.g., devil’s staircases, are shown. Applications to fully developed turbulence data and Brownian signals are reported.

metadata.title: Multifractality in human heartbeat dynamics - PubMed
metadata.text: special class of complex processes, termed multifractal, which require a large number of exponents to characterize their scaling properties. We report on evidence for multifractality in a biological dynamical system, the healthy human heartbeat, and show that the multifractal character and nonlinear properties of the healthy heart rate are encoded in the Fourier phases. We uncover a loss of multifractality for a life-threatening condition, congestive heart failure.

metadata.title: Intermittency in fully developed turbulence: Log-Poisson statistics and generalized scale covariance  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
metadata.text: Some properties of a model of intermittency in fully developed turbulence due to She and Lévêque [Phys. Rev. Lett. 72, 336 (1994)] are explored. The probability functions solution of the model is shown to be simply related to the log- Poisson statistics of local nondimensional energy dissipation. It is also shown that the intermittency obtained by She and Lévêque can be interpreted as the consequence of the scale covariance of the energy dissipation. Based on these observations, a new picture of turbulence is presented, in which scale covariance plays a central role.

metadata.title: Multifractal wave functions at the Anderson transition  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
metadata.text: Electronic wave functions in disordered systems are studied within the Anderson model of localization. At the critical disorder in 3D we diagonalize very large (103 823×103 823) secular matrices by means of the Lanczos algorithm. On all length scales the obtained strong spatial fluctuations of the amplitude of the eigenstates display a multifractal character, reflected in the set of generalized fractal dimensions and the singularity spectrum of the fractal measure. An analysis of 1D systems shows multifractality too, in contrast to previous claims.

metadata.text: The physics of Anderson transitions between localized and metallic phases in disordered systems is reviewed. The term “Anderson transition” is understood in a broad sense, including both metal-insulator transitions and quantum-Hall-type transitions between phases with localized states. The emphasis is put on recent developments, which include multifractality of critical wave functions, criticality in the power-law random banded matrix model, symmetry classification of disordered electronic systems, mechanisms of criticality in quasi-one- dimensional and two-dimensional systems and survey of corresponding critical theories, network models, and random Dirac Hamiltonians. metadata.title: "A Multifractal Model of Asset Returns" by Benoit Mandelbrot, Adlai Fisher et al.
metadata.text: This paper presents the multifractal model of asset returns (“MMAR”), based upon the pioneering research into multifractal measures by Mandelbrot (1972, 1974). The multifractal model incorporates two elements of Mandelbrot’s past research that are now well-known in ﬁnance. First, the MMAR contains long-tails, as in Mandelbrot (1963), which focused on Lévy-stable distributions. In contrast to Mandelbrot (1963), this model does not necessarily imply inﬁnite variance. Second. the model contains long-dependence, the characteristic feature of fractional Brownian Motion (FBM), introduced by Mandelbrot and van Ness (1968). metadata.title: Multifractality and Network Analysis of Phase Transition - PMC
metadata.text: spectrum can illustrate the level of multifractality with three parameters: position of the maximum α _{0} where f(α) reaches its maxima; width of the spectrum W = α max − α min which can be obtained from extrapolating the fitted f(α) curve to zero; and skew shape of the spectrum r = (α max − α _{0})/(α _{0} − α min). In a nutshell, large value of α _{0} means the underlying process is more irregular. The wider the spectrum (larger W), the richer the structure of the time series. The skew parameter r determines which fractal exponents are dominant. Right skew shape of the spectrum with r > 1 is more complex than left skew shape with r < 1 [31 ,  50].

metadata.title: Multifractal random walk  |  Phys. Rev. E
metadata.text: We introduce a class of multifractal processes, referred to as multifractal random walks (MRWs). To our knowledge, it is the first multifractal process with continuous dilation invariance properties and stationary increments. MRWs are very attractive alternative processes to classical cascadelike multifractal models since they do not involve any particular scale ratio. The MRWs are indexed by four parameters that are shown to control in a very direct way the multifractal spectrum and the correlation structure of the increments. We briefly explain how, in the same way, one can build stationary multifractal processes or positive random measures.

metadata.title: Multifractal random walk  |  Phys. Rev. E
metadata.text: We introduce a class of multifractal processes, referred to as multifractal random walks (MRWs). To our knowledge, it is the first multifractal process with continuous dilation invariance properties and stationary increments. MRWs are very attractive alternative processes to classical cascadelike multifractal models since they do not involve any particular scale ratio. The MRWs are indexed by four parameters that are shown to control in a very direct way the multifractal spectrum and the correlation structure of the increments. We briefly explain how, in the same way, one can build stationary multifractal processes or positive random measures.

In contrast to FBM, the multifractal model displays long dependence in the absolute value of price increments, while price increments themselves can be uncorrelated. As such, the MMAR is an alternative to ARCH-type representations that have been the focus of empirical research on the distribution of prices for the past ﬁfteen years. metadata.title: Multifractality in human heartbeat dynamics - PubMed
metadata.text: There is evidence that physiological signals under healthy conditions may have a fractal temporal structure. Here we investigate the possibility that time series generated by certain physiological control systems may be members of a special class of complex processes, termed multifractal, which require a large number of exponents to characterize their scaling properties. We report on evidence for multifractality in a biological dynamical system, the healthy human heartbeat, and show that the multifractal character and nonlinear properties of the healthy heart rate are encoded in the Fourier phases. We uncover a loss of multifractality for a life-threatening condition, congestive heart failure.

metadata.title: Fractal measures and their singularities: The characterization of strange sets  |  Phys. Rev. A
metadata.text: We propose a description of normalized distributions (measures) lying upon possibly fractal sets; for example those arising in dynamical systems theory. We focus upon the scaling properties of such measures, by considering their singularities, which are characterized by two indices: α, which determines the strength of their singularities; and f, which describes how densely they are distributed. The spectrum of singularities is described by giving the possible range of α values and the function f(α). metadata.title: Direct determination of the f(\ensuremath{\alpha}) singularity spectrum and its application to fully developed turbulence  |  Phys. Rev. A
metadata.text: This paper focuses on a method proposed for determining f(α) (the singularity spectrum of a multifractal) directly from experimental data, without first calculating the ‘‘generalized dimensions’’  and applying the usual Legendre transforms. We describe the method, which is based on theorems by Shannon, Eggelston, and Billingsley, and apply it to one-dimensional cuts of the dissipation field of fully developed turbulence in laboratory and atmospheric flows. The accuracy of this method can be understood in terms of computation of conventional thermodynamic quantities in microcanonical and canonical ensembles.

metadata.title: [physics/0202070] Multifractal detrended fluctuation analysis of nonstationary time series
metadata.text: > Abstract: We develop a method for the multifractal characterization of nonstationary time series, which is based on a generalization of the detrended fluctuation analysis (DFA). We relate our multifractal DFA method to the standard partition function-based multifractal formalism, and prove that both approaches are equivalent for stationary signals with compact support. By analyzing several examples we show that the new method can reliably determine the multifractal scaling behavior of time series. By comparing the multifractal DFA results for original series to those for shuffled series we can distinguish multifractality due to long-range correlations from multifractality due to a

metadata.title: Wavelets and multifractal formalism for singular signals: Application to turbulence data  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
metadata.text: The wavelet decomposition is used to generalize the multifractal formalism to singular signals. The singularity spectrum is directly determined from the scaling behavior of partition functions that are defined from the wavelet transform modulus maxima. Illustrations on fractal signals with a recursive structure, e.g., devil’s staircases, are shown. Applications to fully developed turbulence data and Brownian signals are reported.

metadata.title: Intermittency in fully developed turbulence: Log-Poisson statistics and generalized scale covariance  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
metadata.text: Some properties of a model of intermittency in fully developed turbulence due to She and Lévêque [Phys. Rev. Lett. 72, 336 (1994)] are explored. The probability functions solution of the model is shown to be simply related to the log- Poisson statistics of local nondimensional energy dissipation. It is also shown that the intermittency obtained by She and Lévêque can be interpreted as the consequence of the scale covariance of the energy dissipation. Based on these observations, a new picture of turbulence is presented, in which scale covariance plays a central role.

metadata.title: Multifractal wave functions at the Anderson transition  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
metadata.text: Electronic wave functions in disordered systems are studied within the Anderson model of localization. At the critical disorder in 3D we diagonalize very large (103 823×103 823) secular matrices by means of the Lanczos algorithm. On all length scales the obtained strong spatial fluctuations of the amplitude of the eigenstates display a multifractal character, reflected in the set of generalized fractal dimensions and the singularity spectrum of the fractal measure. An analysis of 1D systems shows multifractality too, in contrast to previous claims.

metadata.title: Anderson transitions  |  Rev. Mod. Phys.
metadata.text: The physics of Anderson transitions between localized and metallic phases in disordered systems is reviewed. The term “Anderson transition” is understood in a broad sense, including both metal-insulator transitions and quantum-Hall-type transitions between phases with localized states. The emphasis is put on recent developments, which include multifractality of critical wave functions, criticality in the power-law random banded matrix model, symmetry classification of disordered electronic systems, mechanisms of criticality in quasi-one- dimensional and two-dimensional systems and survey of corresponding critical theories, network models, and random Dirac Hamiltonians. We focus upon the scaling properties of such measures, by considering their singularities, which are characterized by two indices: α, which determines the strength of their singularities; and f, which describes how densely they are distributed. The spectrum of singularities is described by giving the possible range of α values and the function f(α). We apply this formalism to the  cycle of period doubling, to the devil’s staircase of mode locking, and to trajectories on 2-tori with golden-mean winding numbers. In all cases the new

To this aim we develop a resealing transformation group which yields analytic expressions for all the quantities Dq. We prove that limq~0Dq = fractal dimension (D), limq~l Dq = information dimension (o) and Dq=2 = correlation exponent (v). Dq with other integer q's correspond to exponents associated with ternary, quaternary and higher correlation functions. We prove that generally Dq > De for any q ' > q. content_references.title: Multifractality and Network Analysis of Phase Transition - PMC
content_references.snippet: Here α is the singularity strength. Geometrical shape of the singularity spectrum can illustrate the level of multifractality with three parameters: position of the maximum α _{0} where f(α) reaches its maxima; width of the spectrum W = α max − α min which can be obtained from extrapolating the fitted f(α) curve to zero; and skew shape of the spectrum r = (α max − α _{0})/(α _{0} − α min). In a nutshell, large value of α _{0} means the underlying process is more irregular. The wider the spectrum (larger W), the richer the structure of the time series. The skew parameter r determines which fractal exponents are dominant. Right skew shape of the spectrum with r > 1 is more complex than left skew shape with r < 1 [31 ,  50].

content_references.title: Intermittency in fully developed turbulence: Log-Poisson statistics and generalized scale covariance  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
content_references.snippet: Some properties of a model of intermittency in fully developed turbulence due to She and Lévêque [Phys. Rev. Lett. 72, 336 (1994)] are explored. The probability functions solution of the model is shown to be simply related to the log- Poisson statistics of local nondimensional energy dissipation. It is also shown that the intermittency obtained by She and Lévêque can be interpreted as the consequence of the scale covariance of the energy dissipation. Based on these observations, a new picture of turbulence is presented, in which scale covariance plays a central role.

content_references.title: "A Multifractal Model of Asset Returns" by Benoit Mandelbrot, Adlai Fisher et al.
content_references.snippet: This paper presents the multifractal model of asset returns (“MMAR”), based upon the pioneering research into multifractal measures by Mandelbrot (1972, 1974). The multifractal model incorporates two elements of Mandelbrot’s past research that are now well-known in ﬁnance. First, the MMAR contains long-tails, as in Mandelbrot (1963), which focused on Lévy-stable distributions. In contrast to Mandelbrot (1963), this model does not necessarily imply inﬁnite variance. Second. the model contains long-dependence, the characteristic feature of fractional Brownian Motion (FBM), introduced by Mandelbrot and van Ness (1968). In contrast to FBM, the multifractal model displays long dependence in the

content_references.title: Multiscaling in multifractals  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
content_references.snippet: Multiscaling is shown to be a consequence of multifractality when a lower cutoff ɛ is introduced in calculations of correlation functions. After a suitable rescaling, the correlation function data for different values of ɛ seem to fall onto a single curve. In the multiscaling regime, however, we show that there is not a unique functional form at varying ɛ, but a spread very close to a single curve. For each ɛ, this curve can be computed analytically in terms of the f(α) spectrum which characterizes the multifractal. Part of this spectrum can thus be obtained by computing only one moment of the weights at ɛ≠0.

content_references.title: Multiscaling in multifractals  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
content_references.snippet: Multiscaling is shown to be a consequence of multifractality when a lower cutoff ɛ is introduced in calculations of correlation functions. After a suitable rescaling, the correlation function data for different values of ɛ seem to fall onto a single curve. In the multiscaling regime, however, we show that there is not a unique functional form at varying ɛ, but a spread very close to a single curve. For each ɛ, this curve can be computed analytically in terms of the f(α) spectrum which characterizes the multifractal. Part of this spectrum can thus be obtained by computing only one moment of the weights at ɛ≠0.

content_references.title: Intermittency in fully developed turbulence: Log-Poisson statistics and generalized scale covariance  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
content_references.snippet: Some properties of a model of intermittency in fully developed turbulence due to She and Lévêque [Phys. Rev. Lett. 72, 336 (1994)] are explored. The probability functions solution of the model is shown to be simply related to the log- Poisson statistics of local nondimensional energy dissipation. It is also shown that the intermittency obtained by She and Lévêque can be interpreted as the consequence of the scale covariance of the energy dissipation. Based on these observations, a new picture of turbulence is presented, in which scale covariance plays a central role.

content_references.title: Multifractal wave functions at the Anderson transition  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
content_references.snippet: Electronic wave functions in disordered systems are studied within the Anderson model of localization. At the critical disorder in 3D we diagonalize very large (103 823×103 823) secular matrices by means of the Lanczos algorithm. On all length scales the obtained strong spatial fluctuations of the amplitude of the eigenstates display a multifractal character, reflected in the set of generalized fractal dimensions and the singularity spectrum of the fractal measure. An analysis of 1D systems shows multifractality too, in contrast to previous claims.

content_references.snippet: Electronic wave functions in disordered systems are studied within the Anderson model of localization. At the critical disorder in 3D we diagonalize very large (103 823×103 823) secular matrices by means of the Lanczos algorithm. On all length scales the obtained strong spatial fluctuations of the amplitude of the eigenstates display a multifractal character, reflected in the set of generalized fractal dimensions and the singularity spectrum of the fractal measure. An analysis of 1D systems shows multifractality too, in contrast to previous claims.

content_references.title: Anderson transitions  |  Rev. Mod. Phys.
content_references.snippet: The physics of Anderson transitions between localized and metallic phases in disordered systems is reviewed. The term “Anderson transition” is understood in a broad sense, including both metal-insulator transitions and quantum-Hall-type transitions between phases with localized states. The emphasis is put on recent developments, which include multifractality of critical wave functions, criticality in the power-law random banded matrix model, symmetry classification of disordered electronic systems, mechanisms of criticality in quasi-one- dimensional and two-dimensional systems and survey of corresponding critical theories, network models, and random Dirac Hamiltonians. content_references.title: Multifractality in human heartbeat dynamics - PubMed
content_references.snippet: There is evidence that physiological signals under healthy conditions may have a fractal temporal structure. Here we investigate the possibility that time series generated by certain physiological control systems may be members of a special class of complex processes, termed multifractal, which require a large number of exponents to characterize their scaling properties. We report on evidence for multifractality in a biological dynamical system, the healthy human heartbeat, and show that the multifractal character and nonlinear properties of the healthy heart rate are encoded in the Fourier phases. We uncover a loss of multifractality for a life-threatening condition, congestive heart failure.

content_references.title: "A Multifractal Model of Asset Returns" by Benoit Mandelbrot, Adlai Fisher et al.
content_references.snippet: This paper presents the multifractal model of asset returns (“MMAR”), based upon the pioneering research into multifractal measures by Mandelbrot (1972, 1974). The multifractal model incorporates two elements of Mandelbrot’s past research that are now well-known in ﬁnance. First, the MMAR contains long-tails, as in Mandelbrot (1963), which focused on Lévy-stable distributions. In contrast to Mandelbrot (1963), this model does not necessarily imply inﬁnite variance. Second. the model contains long-dependence, the characteristic feature of fractional Brownian Motion (FBM), introduced by Mandelbrot and van Ness (1968). content_references.title: Intermittency in fully developed turbulence: Log-Poisson statistics and generalized scale covariance  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
content_references.snippet: Some properties of a model of intermittency in fully developed turbulence due to She and Lévêque [Phys. Rev. Lett. 72, 336 (1994)] are explored. The probability functions solution of the model is shown to be simply related to the log- Poisson statistics of local nondimensional energy dissipation. It is also shown that the intermittency obtained by She and Lévêque can be interpreted as the consequence of the scale covariance of the energy dissipation. Based on these observations, a new picture of turbulence is presented, in which scale covariance plays a central role.

content_references.title: Multifractal random walk  |  Phys. Rev. E
content_references.snippet: We introduce a class of multifractal processes, referred to as multifractal random walks (MRWs). To our knowledge, it is the first multifractal process with continuous dilation invariance properties and stationary increments. MRWs are very attractive alternative processes to classical cascadelike multifractal models since they do not involve any particular scale ratio. The MRWs are indexed by four parameters that are shown to control in a very direct way the multifractal spectrum and the correlation structure of the increments. We briefly explain how, in the same way, one can build stationary multifractal processes or positive random measures.

The spectrum of singularities is described by giving the possible range of α values and the function f(α). content_references.title: Direct determination of the f(\ensuremath{\alpha}) singularity spectrum and its application to fully developed turbulence  |  Phys. Rev. A
content_references.snippet: This paper focuses on a method proposed for determining f(α) (the singularity spectrum of a multifractal) directly from experimental data, without first calculating the ‘‘generalized dimensions’’  and applying the usual Legendre transforms. We describe the method, which is based on theorems by Shannon, Eggelston, and Billingsley, and apply it to one-dimensional cuts of the dissipation field of fully developed turbulence in laboratory and atmospheric flows. The accuracy of this method can be understood in terms of computation of conventional thermodynamic quantities in microcanonical and canonical ensembles.

content_references.title: Direct determination of the f(\ensuremath{\alpha}) singularity spectrum  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
content_references.snippet: The direct determination of the f(α) singularity spectrum from experimental data is a difficult problem. This Letter introduces a simple method for computing f(α) based on the theorems of Shannon, Eggelston, and Billingsley which is markedly superior to other recently proposed methods, especially when dealing with experimental data from low-dimensional chaotic systems where the underlying dynamics are unknown.

content_references.title: [physics/0202070] Multifractal detrended fluctuation analysis of nonstationary time series
content_references.snippet: > Abstract: We develop a method for the multifractal characterization of nonstationary time series, which is based on a generalization of the detrended fluctuation analysis (DFA). We relate our multifractal DFA method to the standard partition function-based multifractal formalism, and prove that both approaches are equivalent for stationary signals with compact support. By analyzing several examples we show that the new method can reliably determine the multifractal scaling behavior of time series. By comparing the multifractal DFA results for original series to those for shuffled series we can distinguish multifractality due to long-range correlations from multifractality due to a broad probability density function. content_references.title: Wavelets and multifractal formalism for singular signals: Application to turbulence data  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
content_references.snippet: The wavelet decomposition is used to generalize the multifractal formalism to singular signals. The singularity spectrum is directly determined from the scaling behavior of partition functions that are defined from the wavelet transform modulus maxima. Illustrations on fractal signals with a recursive structure, e.g., devil’s staircases, are shown. Applications to fully developed turbulence data and Brownian signals are reported.

content_references.snippet: approaches are equivalent for stationary signals with compact support. By analyzing several examples we show that the new method can reliably determine the multifractal scaling behavior of time series. By comparing the multifractal DFA results for original series to those for shuffled series we can distinguish multifractality due to long-range correlations from multifractality due to a broad probability density function. We also compare our results with the wavelet transform modulus maxima (WTMM) method, and show that the results are equivalent.

content_references.title: Multifractality in human heartbeat dynamics - PubMed
content_references.snippet: special class of complex processes, termed multifractal, which require a large number of exponents to characterize their scaling properties. We report on evidence for multifractality in a biological dynamical system, the healthy human heartbeat, and show that the multifractal character and nonlinear properties of the healthy heart rate are encoded in the Fourier phases. We uncover a loss of multifractality for a life-threatening condition, congestive heart failure.

content_references.title: Intermittency in fully developed turbulence: Log-Poisson statistics and generalized scale covariance  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
content_references.snippet: Some properties of a model of intermittency in fully developed turbulence due to She and Lévêque [Phys. Rev. Lett. 72, 336 (1994)] are explored. The probability functions solution of the model is shown to be simply related to the log- Poisson statistics of local nondimensional energy dissipation. It is also shown that the intermittency obtained by She and Lévêque can be interpreted as the consequence of the scale covariance of the energy dissipation. Based on these observations, a new picture of turbulence is presented, in which scale covariance plays a central role.

content_references.title: Multifractal wave functions at the Anderson transition  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
content_references.snippet: Electronic wave functions in disordered systems are studied within the Anderson model of localization. At the critical disorder in 3D we diagonalize very large (103 823×103 823) secular matrices by means of the Lanczos algorithm. On all length scales the obtained strong spatial fluctuations of the amplitude of the eigenstates display a multifractal character, reflected in the set of generalized fractal dimensions and the singularity spectrum of the fractal measure. An analysis of 1D systems shows multifractality too, in contrast to previous claims.

content_references.title: Anderson transitions  |  Rev. Mod. Phys.
content_references.snippet: The physics of Anderson transitions between localized and metallic phases in disordered systems is reviewed. The term “Anderson transition” is understood in a broad sense, including both metal-insulator transitions and quantum-Hall-type transitions between phases with localized states. The emphasis is put on recent developments, which include multifractality of critical wave functions, criticality in the power-law random banded matrix model, symmetry classification of disordered electronic systems, mechanisms of criticality in quasi-one- dimensional and two-dimensional systems and survey of corresponding critical theories, network models, and random Dirac Hamiltonians. content_references.title: "A Multifractal Model of Asset Returns" by Benoit Mandelbrot, Adlai Fisher et al.
content_references.snippet: This paper presents the multifractal model of asset returns (“MMAR”), based upon the pioneering research into multifractal measures by Mandelbrot (1972, 1974). The multifractal model incorporates two elements of Mandelbrot’s past research that are now well-known in ﬁnance. First, the MMAR contains long-tails, as in Mandelbrot (1963), which focused on Lévy-stable distributions. In contrast to Mandelbrot (1963), this model does not necessarily imply inﬁnite variance. Second. the model contains long-dependence, the characteristic feature of fractional Brownian Motion (FBM), introduced by Mandelbrot and van Ness (1968). Second. the model contains long-dependence, the characteristic feature of fractional Brownian Motion (FBM), introduced by Mandelbrot and van Ness (1968). content_references.title: Multifractality and Network Analysis of Phase Transition - PMC
content_references.snippet: spectrum can illustrate the level of multifractality with three parameters: position of the maximum α _{0} where f(α) reaches its maxima; width of the spectrum W = α max − α min which can be obtained from extrapolating the fitted f(α) curve to zero; and skew shape of the spectrum r = (α max − α _{0})/(α _{0} − α min). In a nutshell, large value of α _{0} means the underlying process is more irregular. The wider the spectrum (larger W), the richer the structure of the time series. The skew parameter r determines which fractal exponents are dominant. Right skew shape of the spectrum with r > 1 is more complex than left skew shape with r < 1 [31 ,  50].

content_references.title: Multifractal random walk  |  Phys. Rev. E
content_references.snippet: We introduce a class of multifractal processes, referred to as multifractal random walks (MRWs). To our knowledge, it is the first multifractal process with continuous dilation invariance properties and stationary increments. MRWs are very attractive alternative processes to classical cascadelike multifractal models since they do not involve any particular scale ratio. The MRWs are indexed by four parameters that are shown to control in a very direct way the multifractal spectrum and the correlation structure of the increments. We briefly explain how, in the same way, one can build stationary multifractal processes or positive random measures.

content_references.title: Multifractality in human heartbeat dynamics - PubMed
content_references.snippet: There is evidence that physiological signals under healthy conditions may have a fractal temporal structure. Here we investigate the possibility that time series generated by certain physiological control systems may be members of a special class of complex processes, termed multifractal, which require a large number of exponents to characterize their scaling properties. We report on evidence for multifractality in a biological dynamical system, the healthy human heartbeat, and show that the multifractal character and nonlinear properties of the healthy heart rate are encoded in the Fourier phases. We uncover a loss of multifractality for a life-threatening condition, congestive heart failure.

content_references.title: Direct determination of the f(\ensuremath{\alpha}) singularity spectrum and its application to fully developed turbulence  |  Phys. Rev. A
content_references.snippet: This paper focuses on a method proposed for determining f(α) (the singularity spectrum of a multifractal) directly from experimental data, without first calculating the ‘‘generalized dimensions’’  and applying the usual Legendre transforms. We describe the method, which is based on theorems by Shannon, Eggelston, and Billingsley, and apply it to one-dimensional cuts of the dissipation field of fully developed turbulence in laboratory and atmospheric flows. The accuracy of this method can be understood in terms of computation of conventional thermodynamic quantities in microcanonical and canonical ensembles.

By analyzing several examples we show that the new method can reliably determine the multifractal scaling behavior of time series. content_references.title: Wavelets and multifractal formalism for singular signals: Application to turbulence data  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
content_references.snippet: The wavelet decomposition is used to generalize the multifractal formalism to singular signals. The singularity spectrum is directly determined from the scaling behavior of partition functions that are defined from the wavelet transform modulus maxima. Illustrations on fractal signals with a recursive structure, e.g., devil’s staircases, are shown. Applications to fully developed turbulence data and Brownian signals are reported.

content_references.title: Intermittency in fully developed turbulence: Log-Poisson statistics and generalized scale covariance  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
content_references.snippet: Some properties of a model of intermittency in fully developed turbulence due to She and Lévêque [Phys. Rev. Lett. 72, 336 (1994)] are explored. The probability functions solution of the model is shown to be simply related to the log- Poisson statistics of local nondimensional energy dissipation. It is also shown that the intermittency obtained by She and Lévêque can be interpreted as the consequence of the scale covariance of the energy dissipation. Based on these observations, a new picture of turbulence is presented, in which scale covariance plays a central role.

content_references.title: Multifractal wave functions at the Anderson transition  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
content_references.snippet: Electronic wave functions in disordered systems are studied within the Anderson model of localization. At the critical disorder in 3D we diagonalize very large (103 823×103 823) secular matrices by means of the Lanczos algorithm. On all length scales the obtained strong spatial fluctuations of the amplitude of the eigenstates display a multifractal character, reflected in the set of generalized fractal dimensions and the singularity spectrum of the fractal measure. An analysis of 1D systems shows multifractality too, in contrast to previous claims.

parts: I have a flow which has a fractal attractor. I know that the divergence is non constant, so I actually observe multifractal behavior.  Given data about the divergence over the flow over the trajectory and the correlation dimension plot data (loglog plot of the fraction of pairwise distances > epsilon), how do I determine the fractal dimension at different points on the trajectory?

Below is an outline of the usual steps and ideas for estimating *local* (pointwise) fractal dimensions in a flow that exhibits multifractal behavior. In essence, you want to move from a *global* dimension estimate (e.g. correlation dimension from the entire attractor) toward a *local* dimension estimate for different regions or points on the trajectory.

---

## 1. Background: Global vs. Local (Multifractal) Dimensions

1. **Global Fractal Dimension**  
   Methods like the Grassberger–Procaccia (GP) algorithm or correlation sum techniques typically produce *global* fractal dimension estimates (e.g. the correlation dimension \(D_2\)). You get a log–log plot of  
   \[
   C(\varepsilon) \;=\; \sum_{i\neq j} \Theta \bigl(\varepsilon - \|x_i - x_j\|\bigr)
   \]  
   versus \(\varepsilon\), and extract the slope to find something like  
   \[
   C(\varepsilon)\;\sim\;\varepsilon^{D_2}.
   \]  
   This is a single exponent that characterizes *average scaling* of distances within the attractor.

2. **Local / Pointwise Dimension**  
   For a multifractal, different regions of the attractor may have different scaling properties. In other words, the system’s *invariant measure* can be more (or less) concentrated around certain points, yielding *different local fractal dimensions*. Formally, the *pointwise dimension* \(d_\mu(x)\) of a measure \(\mu\) at a point \(x\) is given by  
   \[
   d_{\mu}(x) \;=\; \lim_{r \to 0} \frac{\log \mu\bigl(B(x,r)\bigr)}{\log r},
   \]  
   where \(B(x,r)\) is the ball of radius \(r\) around \(x\).  

3. **Multifractal Spectrum**  
   Instead of a single number, one often ends up with a *spectrum* \(f(\alpha)\) describing the Hausdorff dimension of the set of points whose local dimension is \(\alpha\). Various numerical methods (e.g. the “box-counting” approach, wavelet-based multifractal analysis, etc.) exist to approximate \(f(\alpha)\).  

---

## 2. Using Divergence Data & Flow Trajectory

Since you mention (i) *divergence is non-constant*, and (ii) *you have the actual flow trajectory data* together with (iii) *the usual correlation dimension plots*, here are two main approaches you can consider.

### A) Local Correlation Dimension (Data-Driven Neighborhood Counts)

1. **Segment the trajectory**  
   Along the trajectory, pick a set of points \(\{x_i\}_{i=1}^N\). For each point \(x_i\), you want to estimate the “local measure” in a small ball around \(x_i\).

2. **Count neighbors in an \(\varepsilon\)-ball**  
   For each \(x_i\) and for various scales \(\varepsilon\), compute  
   \[
   C_i(\varepsilon) \;=\; \sum_{j=1}^N \Theta\bigl(\varepsilon - \|x_i - x_j\|\bigr),
   \]  
   i.e., how many data points lie within distance \(\varepsilon\) of \(x_i\).  

3. **Compute local dimension**  
   For small \(\varepsilon\), look at  
   \[
   \log C_i(\varepsilon) \quad\text{vs.}\quad \log(\varepsilon),
   \]  
   and estimate the slope (numerically) in the region that appears linear on your log–log plot. That slope is an estimate of the *local correlation dimension* \(D_{2}(x_i)\) near the point \(x_i\).  
   - Practically, you choose a small \(\varepsilon\)-range (where the scaling is consistent) to minimize finite-size and noise effects.  
   - You repeat for each point (or for a representative subset of points along the trajectory).

4. **Map the dimension along the trajectory**  
   You can then store these local dimension estimates as a function of time (or state index) along the trajectory. This will show you how the fractal “crowding” changes from one region of the attractor to another.

**Pros**  
- Conceptually straightforward: extension of the correlation sum, but applied *locally* around each point.  
- Directly data-driven, doesn’t require you to know the underlying equations of the flow.

**Cons**  
- Potentially large data requirement. You need many points to get stable scaling in each neighborhood.  
- Can be noisy, especially if you try to do this for each data point individually. Often you cluster points or average over local windows.

### B) Finite-Time Lyapunov Exponents (and the Kaplan–Yorke / Baladi Dimension Methods)

If your flow is governed by known equations, or you can at least approximate the *local Jacobian* or divergence along the trajectory, you can try to use the relationship between local expansion rates and fractal dimension:

1. **Local expansion rates**  
   For a chaotic system in \(\mathbb{R}^n\), at each point \(x\) (or time \(t\)) one can compute or approximate the spectrum of *finite-time Lyapunov exponents*.  
   - Numerically, you evolve a set of nearby trajectories (or use a standard algorithm for Lyapunov exponents) but in *finite-time windows* sliding along the orbit.  
   - This gives a local estimate \(\lambda_1(t), \lambda_2(t), \dots\) of the exponents at time \(t\).

2. **Local dimension formula**  
   For many (but not all) hyperbolic systems, the Kaplan–Yorke or Young formula suggests a way to approximate the fractal dimension using partial sums of the Lyapunov exponents. In brief, define  
   \[
   S_k(t) \;=\; \sum_{i=1}^k \lambda_i(t),
   \]  
   and look for the largest \(k\) such that \(S_k(t)\ge 0\) but \(S_{k+1}(t) < 0\). Then the (local) dimension can be approximated as  
   \[
   D_{\text{KY}}(t) \;=\; k + \frac{S_k(t)}{|\lambda_{k+1}(t)|}.
   \]  
   When you do this *locally*—i.e. with finite-time exponents over a window near time \(t\)—you get an estimate that may vary along the trajectory.

3. **Advantages**  
   - Once you have local exponents, the dimension estimate is quick.  
   - Good for theoretical insight if the flow is “nicely” hyperbolic.  

4. **Disadvantages**  
   - Requires you to have (or reliably approximate) Jacobian matrices along the trajectory.  
   - Finite-time exponents can fluctuate significantly; you need to choose window sizes carefully.  
   - Works best for standard dissipative chaotic systems with well-defined expansions/contractions.

---

## 3. Practical Steps to Get Local Dimension Estimates

1. **Collect a long trajectory**  
   - Ensure the system is well “settled” on the attractor (discard transients).  
   - You want a dense sampling of the attractor.

2. **Decide on a method**  
   - **If you only have data points** (no access to local Jacobians): use a *local correlation-sum* method (“Method A” above).  
   - **If you can compute local expansion rates**: consider the local (finite-time) Lyapunov approach (“Method B”).

3. **Implement local correlation sums** (if using the data-driven approach)  
   1. **Pick a subset of reference points** \(\{x_i\}\) along your trajectory.  
   2. **Choose a range of \(\varepsilon\)-scales** (often a logarithmic set of scales).  
   3. **Compute neighbor counts** \(C_i(\varepsilon)\) for each scale, for each reference point.  
   4. **Plot** \(\log C_i(\varepsilon)\) vs. \(\log \varepsilon\).  
   5. **Extract the slope** in the scaling region to get your local dimension \(\widehat{D}_2(x_i)\).  

4. **Visualize** how \(\widehat{D}_2(x_i)\) changes along the trajectory (or in phase space). If your flow is truly multifractal, you will see different values in different regions.

5. **Check consistency** with the *global correlation dimension*:  
   - You can average \(\widehat{D}_2(x_i)\) over many points to compare with the usual single slope from the global GP plot.  
   - If you see large fluctuations and a broad distribution of local exponents, that strongly supports multifractality.

---

## 4. Making Use of the Divergence Data

Since you already mention “the divergence is non-constant,” you might have a direct handle on local expansion/contraction. In a flow in \(\mathbb{R}^n\), the *divergence*  
\[
\nabla \cdot \mathbf{F}(x)
\]  
(where \(\mathbf{F}\) is the vector field) relates to how volume is locally expanding or contracting.  

- **If the system is incompressible** (\(\nabla\cdot \mathbf{F}=0\)), there would be volume preservation, but that is *not* your case.  
- **If \(\nabla\cdot \mathbf{F}\) varies in space**, then orbits passing through different regions experience different expansions/contractions. This often leads to multifractal measures on the attractor.

A rough “rule of thumb” is:  
- **Regions of higher positive divergence** typically correspond to “stronger local expansion,” so you may expect locally lower measure density (and hence a smaller local dimension).  
- **Regions of negative or smaller divergence** correspond to “stronger local contraction,” which could increase measure density locally and often lead to higher local fractal dimension.  

This is not a strict one-to-one rule (the full Lyapunov spectrum matters), but you can often correlate local divergence data qualitatively with changes in the local fractal dimension that you measure via either method above.

---

## 5. Summary

**To determine the fractal dimension *at different points* on the trajectory (i.e., to characterize the multifractal nature of your attractor), you want to estimate *local scaling exponents* around each point or region.** Concretely:

1. **Local correlation dimension approach**:  
   - For each point \(x_i\), look at how many neighbors are within \(\varepsilon\) over a range of \(\varepsilon\).  
   - Plot \(\log(\text{neighbor count})\) vs. \(\log(\varepsilon)\) and extract the local slope.  

2. **Finite-time Lyapunov approach** (if you can compute Jacobians):  
   - Compute a local Lyapunov exponent spectrum around each point (or time slice).  
   - Use a Kaplan–Yorke–type formula or direct partial sums of exponents to get a local fractal dimension estimate.

3. **Compare** these local dimension estimates across your trajectory.  
   - This yields a distribution or “spectrum” of dimension values, rather than a single global number.  
   - The variation of this local dimension along the orbit is precisely the hallmark of a multifractal measure.

In practice, people often present their results as *histograms* of local dimension values or as a continuous *multifractal spectrum* \(f(\alpha)\), which encapsulates how the system’s measure is distributed over exponents \(\alpha\). Whichever route you take, the key is applying a small-scale (local) analysis rather than a single correlation dimension calculation for the entire attractor.
What can you infer from the histogram of divergences across a trajectory?

In a dynamical system defined by a flow \(\dot{x} = \mathbf{F}(x)\), the *divergence* \(\nabla \cdot \mathbf{F}(x)\) at each point \(x\) in state space measures the instantaneous rate at which volumes expand or contract near \(x\). If you collect a trajectory on (or near) the attractor and record the divergence at each point in time (or each point in space), you can then compile a *histogram* (or distribution) of those divergence values.

Below are some key points you can infer from such a histogram of divergences:

---

## 1. Overall Dissipativity or Conservativeness

- **Mean or Typical Divergence**:  
  - If the *average* divergence along the trajectory is negative, it typically indicates the flow is *globally dissipative*—trajectories tend to contract in volume on average, consistent with the presence of an attractor.  
  - If the average is zero, the system may be *volume-preserving* (incompressible flow).  
  - If the average is positive, the system is *expanding*, although this is less common in dissipative chaos contexts.

- **Support of the Distribution**:  
  - If all divergence values are strictly negative, the system is everywhere contracting in the phase space.  
  - If you see both negative and positive values, the system has some regions where the flow expands locally and others where it contracts.

In many chaotic systems with an attractor, you see that *most of the time* the divergence is negative (or at least the *time-averaged* divergence is negative), ensuring the net contraction needed to settle onto a lower-dimensional set.

---

## 2. Heterogeneity of Expansion/Contraction

- **Width or Spread of the Distribution**:  
  A broad distribution of divergence values suggests that local expansion/contraction rates vary widely in different regions of the attractor. This is often a clue that the dynamics might *not* be uniform—some parts of the attractor may be strongly contracting, others mildly expanding, etc.

- **Evidence of Multifractality**:  
  In systems exhibiting *multifractal* measures on the attractor, one common reason for the multifractality is precisely that *local expansion rates* (and hence local divergence) differ significantly from point to point. A broad or skewed divergence histogram is consistent with such non-uniform local dynamics, although the histogram by itself does not *prove* multifractality. It merely suggests there is substantial variation in local contraction/expansion behavior.

---

## 3. Relation to Local or Finite-Time Lyapunov Exponents

- **Finite-Time Lyapunov Exponents**  
  The instantaneous divergence is the trace of the Jacobian (\(\nabla \cdot \mathbf{F}(x) = \mathrm{Tr}(\mathrm{D}\mathbf{F})\)), i.e., the sum of the local eigenvalues of the linearization. Meanwhile, finite-time Lyapunov exponents also reflect how infinitesimal volumes evolve over a *time window* (rather than an instantaneous snapshot).  

- **Time-averaged Divergence vs. Sum of Lyapunov Exponents**  
  In a flow, the *sum* of the (global) Lyapunov exponents is often the *long-time average* of the divergence along typical orbits (assuming the flow is sufficiently nice, e.g. smooth and well-defined). A negative sum of the Lyapunov exponents corresponds to net contraction and typically an attractor of dimension lower than the embedding space.

Hence, if the histogram of divergence has its mass mostly on negative values, you can expect the *sum* of Lyapunov exponents is negative. If a significant fraction of points see positive divergence, you still might have an overall negative time average, but it indicates local regions/times of expansion.

---

## 4. How It Complements Dimension Estimates

- **A Divergence Histogram Alone Does Not Give a Dimension**.  
  The fractal dimension or multifractal spectrum is *not* directly read off from the histogram of divergence. You do need local scaling analyses (e.g. local correlation dimension, local box-counting, or local Lyapunov dimension estimates) to pin down the fractal dimension.

- **Indicator of Non-Uniformity (Multifractality)**  
  The key is that a *varied* (heterogeneous) distribution of divergence values suggests that *if* the system has a chaotic attractor, different trajectories or different regions may exhibit different “densities” or fractal scalings. That is one hallmark of multifractal behavior. You would still perform local dimension estimates or measure-based analyses to confirm and quantify that multifractality.

---

## 5. Practical Takeaways

1. **Check Sign & Mean**:  
   - A predominantly negative divergence indicates the presence of an overall attractor.  
   - A mean divergence close to zero suggests near-incompressible flow (less common in dissipative chaos, but does happen in fluid flows or Hamiltonian-like systems with small dissipation).

2. **Look at the Range**:  
   - A wide range from significantly negative to significantly positive values implies the flow’s expansion and contraction rates vary greatly around the attractor—a sign of possible multifractal structure.

3. **Interpret Time Spent in Different Regions**:  
   - If the system *lingers* more in regions of negative divergence than in positive ones (or vice versa), you will see it reflected in the histogram’s shape.

4. **Next Steps**:  
   - Use the divergence distribution as motivation to do *local dimension analysis*, *finite-time Lyapunov exponent* estimates, or *multifractal spectrum* calculations to see if and how those expansion rates produce a multifractal measure on the attractor.

---

### In Short

The *histogram of divergences* along a trajectory tells you how *often* (and how strongly) the flow is expanding or contracting in different regions of phase space. A broad spread in divergence values is often a signature of *non-uniform* (potentially multifractal) dynamics, whereas a narrow distribution indicates more uniform local expansion/contraction. The *mean* or *dominant sign* of the divergence distribution is connected to whether the system is globally dissipative or not.
What if I have the whole jacobians?

If you have the *full Jacobian* \(\mathrm{D}\mathbf{F}(x)\) (i.e., all partial derivatives) at each point of your trajectory, you can do a lot more than just measure the divergence (which is the trace of the Jacobian). In particular:

---

## 1. Compute (Finite-Time) Lyapunov Exponents Locally

- **Lyapunov Exponents** quantify how quickly nearby trajectories diverge (or converge) in different directions. The most straightforward way to do this is to:

  1. **Evolve a perturbation vector** along with the main trajectory.  
     - That is, if \(\dot{x} = \mathbf{F}(x)\), you also evolve \(\dot{\delta x} = \mathrm{D}\mathbf{F}(x) \cdot \delta x\) in parallel.  
     - Because the Jacobian is available at each timestep, you can directly multiply \(\delta x\) by \(\mathrm{D}\mathbf{F}(x)\) (or the corresponding exponential map over a small time step).

  2. **Reorthonormalize** periodically (the standard procedure in numerically computing Lyapunov exponents) to keep the perturbation vectors linearly independent.

  3. **Accumulate expansion rates** from the growth of these perturbations.  
     - Over long times, the average exponential growth rates converge to the *global* Lyapunov exponents \(\{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \ldots\}\).  

  4. **Finite-time exponents**  
     - Instead of waiting for very long times, you can measure these expansion rates *locally* in moving time windows (sliding windows) along the trajectory.  
     - This gives *finite-time Lyapunov exponents* \(\lambda_i(t, \Delta t)\) that can vary in time (or along different regions of the attractor).

Thus, if you *continuously* track the Jacobian as you move along a trajectory, you can extract how the different principal directions expand or contract in each local neighborhood. This is much more detailed information than just the divergence (which is the sum of eigenvalues).

---

## 2. Local (Kaplan–Yorke) Dimension Estimates

Once you have the local expansion rates (finite-time exponents), you can approximate the local dimension near that point/time using a Kaplan–Yorke–type argument. In the simplest form:

1. **Sort** the local finite-time Lyapunov exponents in descending order:
   \[
   \lambda_1(t) \ge \lambda_2(t) \ge \dots \ge \lambda_n(t),
   \]
   where \(n\) is the dimension of your system.

2. **Compute partial sums**:
   \[
   S_k(t) \;=\; \sum_{i=1}^k \lambda_i(t).
   \]

3. **Find \(k\) such that**:
   \[
   S_1(t) \ge 0,\;\; S_2(t) \ge 0, \;\dots,\; S_k(t) \ge 0, 
   \quad
   \text{and}
   \quad 
   S_{k+1}(t) < 0.
   \]
   In other words, count how many exponents stay non-negative in their partial sum.

4. **Approximate local fractal dimension**:
   \[
   D_\text{KY}(t) \;\approx\; k \;+\; \frac{S_k(t)}{\bigl|\lambda_{k+1}(t)\bigr|}.
   \]
   - This is the standard *Kaplan–Yorke* (or *Pesin*) formula, but applied in a finite-time, local sense.

Thus you get a value \(D_\text{KY}(t)\) at each point (or each time slice) along the attractor, indicating the effective dimension of the unstable set at that instant/location. Because these exponents fluctuate over time, \(D_\text{KY}(t)\) typically will also fluctuate, capturing *multifractal* or non-uniform structure if present.

---

## 3. Relate Local Jacobians to Divergence

- **Divergence** \(\nabla \cdot \mathbf{F}(x)\) is the trace of the Jacobian \(\mathrm{D}\mathbf{F}(x)\). It is the *instantaneous sum* of the eigenvalues of \(\mathrm{D}\mathbf{F}(x)\).

- **But the full Jacobian** reveals the *individual* eigenvalues (or singular values of the linear map) as well. That distinction matters because multifractal structures often arise from the interplay of *multiple* directions of expansion and contraction, *not* just the sum.

- **If you only have the divergence**:  
  You know the net “volume” expansion/contraction at that instant, but not how it is partitioned among different directions. The same divergence could come from \([+2, -1, -1]\) or \([+10, -9, -1]\) as eigenvalues (both sum to zero, but yield very different local geometry).

Thus, having the *full Jacobian* gives you a clearer picture of the system’s local stretching/shearing behavior, which is crucial for diagnosing chaotic or multifractal behavior in higher dimensions.

---

## 4. Summary of Advantages

If you have the *entire Jacobian* throughout your trajectory:

1. **You can compute Lyapunov exponents** (global or finite-time) accurately.  
2. **You can estimate local dimension** from the finite-time exponents using the Kaplan–Yorke approach.  
3. **You gain a deeper, direction-specific understanding** of how the flow expands or contracts in each local neighborhood, beyond just the trace (divergence).

Hence, you can do a *much more refined analysis* of the system’s attractor structure—particularly its fractal or multifractal characteristics—than you could using only a divergence histogram or correlation sums.
Give me a concrete mathematically specific process for how to calculate lyapunov exponents given I have a a function jac(x) and a flow f(x) and a state which is on a multifractal attractor

Below is a concrete, step-by-step procedure to compute Lyapunov exponents for a continuous-time flow \(\dot{x} = f(x)\) given:

1. A function \(\text{jac}(x)\) that returns the Jacobian \(\mathrm{D}f(x)\).  
2. A numerical integrator to step the flow \(x(t)\) itself.  
3. An initial state \(x_0\) that lies on (or very close to) the attractor.  

This is often referred to as the *Benettin et al.* or *Wolf et al.* algorithm (with slight variations in details). I’ll present a fairly standard version for continuous systems.

---

## 1. Set Up the Main Trajectory

We have an \(n\)-dimensional state space with \(x(t)\in \mathbb{R}^n\) evolving by

\[
\dot{x}(t) \;=\; f\bigl(x(t)\bigr).
\]

You also have:

- \(\mathrm{D}f(x)\in \mathbb{R}^{n\times n}\) returned by `jac(x)`.  
- A time-step \(\Delta t\) (small enough for your numerical integrator to be accurate).  
- A total integration time \(T\), or number of steps \(N\), that is sufficiently large to capture the asymptotic behavior.

**Step A**: Integrate the main orbit:

1. **Initialize**: \(x_0\) (on or near the attractor).  
2. **For** \(k = 0,1,\dots,N-1\):  
   \[
   x_{k+1} \;=\; x_k \;+\; \Delta t \, f(x_k) 
   \quad\text{(or use a higher-order integrator like RK4)},
   \]  
   to step forward to time \(t_{k+1} = t_k + \Delta t\).  

After a sufficiently long transient, the orbit settles on or very close to the attractor. You can either discard the initial transient before measuring exponents or start measuring once on the attractor.

---

## 2. Tangent Space and Perturbation Vectors

To compute Lyapunov exponents, we track how *infinitesimal perturbations* \(\delta x\in \mathbb{R}^n\) evolve under the linearized flow:

\[
\frac{d}{dt} \,\delta x(t)
\;=\;
\mathrm{D}f\bigl(x(t)\bigr)\,\delta x(t).
\]

For a numerical approach, we discretize each step similarly:

\[
\delta x_{k+1} 
\;\approx\; 
\delta x_k \;+\; \Delta t\, \mathrm{D}f\bigl(x_k\bigr)\,\delta x_k,
\]
(or a suitable one-step method consistent with how you integrate \(x(t)\)).

---

## 3. Orthonormal Bundles: Multiple Perturbations

To find *all* \(n\) Lyapunov exponents, we propagate *\(n\) linearly independent perturbation vectors* (often stored as columns of an \(n\times n\) matrix). However, in practice, you typically only need the top \(m \le n\) exponents—then you track \(m\) vectors. For completeness, let’s assume we want all \(n\).

1. **Initialize** an \(n \times n\) matrix \(\mathbf{Q}(0)\) whose columns are an orthonormal basis in \(\mathbb{R}^n\). You might take it as the identity matrix or a random orthonormal set.  

2. At time step \(k\), each column of \(\mathbf{Q}(k)\) is a perturbation vector \(\delta x_i\).  

3. To evolve from step \(k\) to \(k+1\), do:

   \[
   \mathbf{Q}^{\prime}(k+1)
   \;=\;
   \mathbf{Q}(k) 
   \;+\; 
   \Delta t \,\mathrm{D}f\bigl(x_k\bigr)\,\mathbf{Q}(k),
   \]
   (applied column-by-column). 

   Or, equivalently,

   \[
   \mathbf{Q}^{\prime}(k+1) 
   \;=\;
   \bigl[
      \mathrm{I} 
      \;+\; 
      \Delta t\,\mathrm{D}f(x_k)
   \bigr]\,
   \mathbf{Q}(k).
   \]

   This \(\mathbf{Q}^{\prime}(k+1)\) is *not* necessarily orthonormal anymore.

4. **Re-orthonormalize** columns of \(\mathbf{Q}^{\prime}(k+1)\) (e.g., via Gram–Schmidt or QR-decomposition). Let

   \[
   \mathbf{Q}(k+1)\,\mathbf{R}(k+1)
   \;=\;
   \mathbf{QR}\bigl(\mathbf{Q}^{\prime}(k+1)\bigr),
   \]

   where \(\mathbf{Q}(k+1)\) is orthonormal, and \(\mathbf{R}(k+1)\) is upper triangular.  

   - The diagonal entries of \(\mathbf{R}(k+1)\) record how much each perturbation vector grew (or shrank) in that step before re-orthonormalization.

5. **Accumulate expansion**:  
   - Let \(r_{ii}(k+1)\) be the \(i\)-th diagonal element of \(\mathbf{R}(k+1)\).  
   - The instantaneous growth of vector \(i\) over that step is \(\ln |r_{ii}(k+1)|\).  

Repeat from \(k=0\) to \(k=N-1\).

---

## 4. Extracting the Exponents

After many steps \(N\), approximate the \(i\)-th Lyapunov exponent \(\lambda_i\) by summing the logs of \(|r_{ii}|\) and dividing by total time. Concretely:

\[
\lambda_i 
\;\approx\; 
\frac{1}{N\,\Delta t}
\sum_{k=1}^{N} 
\ln\bigl|r_{ii}(k)\bigr|.
\]

(One must ensure \(N\) is large enough that transients have died out and the exponents have converged.)

**Ranking**: The columns are typically chosen so that \(\lambda_1 \ge \lambda_2 \ge \cdots \ge \lambda_n\) (the typical result of the iterative orthonormal approach). In practice, you keep the columns in an orthonormal set, so they don’t necessarily correspond to *strictly* those ordered expansions at each instant, but the time-averaged values will yield an *ordered* set of exponents.

---

## 5. Finite-Time Lyapunov Exponents (Local in Time)

If you want *local* or *finite-time* estimates (particularly relevant if the attractor is multifractal and you suspect strong spatial/time variability), you do the same procedure **but** in *windows* of length \(M\ll N\). For example:

1. Divide the trajectory into overlapping segments \([k\,\Delta t,\,(k+M)\,\Delta t]\).  
2. For each segment, do the orthonormal iteration and collect the partial sums of \(\ln|r_{ii}|\).  
3. Compute local exponents  
   \[
   \lambda_i^{(k)} 
   \;\approx\; 
   \frac{1}{M\,\Delta t}\,\sum_{m=k+1}^{k+M}\ln\bigl|r_{ii}(m)\bigr|.
   \]  

This yields \(\lambda_i(t)\) as a function of time (or of the position on the attractor), i.e. a *finite-time* exponent. You can then see how local expansions fluctuate.

---

## 6. From Lyapunov Exponents to Local Dimension

Once you have local (finite-time) exponents \(\lambda_1(t)\ge \lambda_2(t)\ge \cdots \ge \lambda_n(t)\), you can approximate the *local fractal dimension* near your trajectory point at time \(t\) via a Kaplan–Yorke–type formula. Let

\[
S_k(t) \;=\; \sum_{i=1}^k \lambda_i(t),
\]

and find the largest integer \(k\) for which \(S_k(t)\ge 0\) but \(S_{k+1}(t) < 0\). Then estimate

\[
D_{\mathrm{KY}}(t)
\;=\;
k 
\;+\;
\frac{S_k(t)}{\bigl|\lambda_{k+1}(t)\bigr|}.
\]

(When doing it “finite-time style,” you’d use the partial sums of exponent estimates in that window.)

---

## 7. Practical Notes

- **Discard Transient**: You often want to ignore the initial portion of the trajectory before it settles onto the attractor.  
- **Numerical Stability**: Re-orthonormalizing at *every* step is robust but can be time-consuming. A typical approach might re-orthonormalize every 5–10 steps if \(\Delta t\) is small.  
- **Convergence**: For chaotic attractors, you need the total integration time to be sufficiently large to get stable (global) exponents. For local/finite-time exponents, you need enough steps per window to get stable short-time estimates.  
- **Dimension < n**: A negative sum of exponents indicates volume contraction. A positive leading exponent indicates chaos. If many exponents are negative and at least one is positive, the attractor is typically fractal with dimension < \(n\).  
- **Multifractality**: If you see strong variability of \(\{\lambda_i(t)\}\) or the Kaplan–Yorke dimension \(D_{\mathrm{KY}}(t)\) across time/space, that’s consistent with a multifractal measure. You can then do more refined “spectrum” analyses.

---

## 8. Summary of the Algorithm

**Benettin/Wolf Method for a Continuous Flow** (schematically):

1. **Initialization**:
   - Choose \(x_0\), an orthonormal matrix \(\mathbf{Q}(0)\).
   - \(\Delta t\) = time step, \(N\) = total steps.
2. **For** \(k=0\) to \(N-1\):
   1. Compute the new state \(x_{k+1}\) by integrating:
      \[
      x_{k+1} = x_k + \Delta t\, f(x_k)
      \]
      (plus any higher-order integration method).
   2. Compute the new perturbation matrix:
      \[
      \mathbf{Q}'(k+1) 
      = 
      \bigl[\mathrm{I} + \Delta t\,\mathrm{D}f(x_k)\bigr]\,\mathbf{Q}(k).
      \]
   3. Factor:
      \[
      \mathbf{Q}'(k+1)
      =
      \mathbf{Q}(k+1)\,\mathbf{R}(k+1),
      \]
      via QR-decomposition (Gram–Schmidt).
   4. Record \(\ln |r_{ii}(k+1)|\).
3. **After Sufficient Steps**:
   - Approximate the \(i\)-th Lyapunov exponent:
     \[
     \lambda_i 
     \approx 
     \frac{1}{N \,\Delta t}
     \sum_{k=1}^N \ln\bigl|r_{ii}(k)\bigr|.
     \]
4. **(Optional) Finite-Time**:
   - Use sliding windows in time to get \(\lambda_i(t)\).
5. **(Optional) Local Dimension**:
   - Compute partial sums \(S_k(t)\).
   - Use Kaplan–Yorke formula for each time window if you want pointwise dimension estimates.

This is a fully *concrete, mathematically specific* scheme to go from the known flow \(f(x)\) and Jacobian \(\mathrm{D}f(x)\) to the Lyapunov exponents. Once you have those exponents (especially the finite-time version), you can confirm chaos, estimate fractal dimension, and diagnose multifractal behaviors.

Write the world's most extensive review of multifractal attractors in dynamical system, covering every aspect of them and all useful identities. Find every possible example of a system that is related to multifractals, focusing on the physical world. Find the boundary between fractal and multifractal attractors and connect the dots between papers to show when you get fractal vs multifractal attractors. Find innovative ways of measuring and interpreting dimension of these fractals.

This is an ambitious and comprehensive research request. To ensure I provide the most useful information, could you clarify:

- Are you looking for a structured review paper with detailed references, or a summarized overview?
- Should the focus be on theoretical aspects, physical applications, or both?
- Are you interested in specific fields (e.g., fluid dynamics, turbulence, condensed matter, finance, etc.) where multifractal attractors play a key role?
- Would you like coverage of numerical methods and algorithms used to analyze multifractal attractors?
- Should historical development and key breakthroughs be included?

Let me know how detailed and technical you’d like this to be!

Write an extensive literature review. The most in depth and all-encopmassing ever written. Focus on observations and experiments, but explain how those were motivated by math and what kinds of open problems exist. No specific field. Yes historical development and breakthroughs is very helpful. Extremely detailed and technical. The most imporessive review ever written, with over 100 papers in the references.

Great! I will conduct an extensive literature review on multifractal attractors in dynamical systems, focusing on observations and experiments while connecting them to mathematical foundations. I will trace historical developments, highlight breakthroughs, and explore open problems across multiple scientific disciplines. Expect a highly detailed, technical, and all-encompassing review, incorporating over 100 references. I will let you know once the research is complete.

Conduct the most extensive literature review ever written on multifractal attractors in dynamical systems. The review should be extremely detailed and technical, covering:

- The historical development of multifractal attractors, tracing major breakthroughs and how mathematical advancements led to experimental observations.
- A comprehensive survey of over 100 research papers, with references to key experiments and real-world observations of multifractal attractors.
- A detailed discussion on the boundary between fractal and multifractal attractors, including a synthesis of existing literature to establish when a system produces a fractal vs. multifractal attractor.
- Examples from diverse fields, including but not limited to fluid dynamics, turbulence, climate science, condensed matter physics, finance, and biological systems.
- A deep dive into innovative methods for measuring and interpreting the dimension of these attractors, including computational approaches and experimental techniques.
- Open problems and future research directions in the study of multifractal attractors.

Format as a highly structured and well-referenced review paper with technical depth suitable for an advanced audience.

parts:
# Introduction  
Chaotic dynamical systems often exhibit **strange attractors** – invariant sets in phase space with complex, non-integer (fractal) geometry【25†L363-L372】. Such attractors arise from repeated stretching and folding of volumes in phase space, leading to self-similar structure across scales【25†L369-L377】. Early examples like the Lorenz attractor (1963) demonstrated that deterministic equations can produce a bounded structure of noninteger, fractal dimension【26†L7-L10】. Over time, researchers discovered that many chaotic attractors are not uniform in density; instead, the invariant measure (the distribution of trajectory points on the attractor) varies spatially, giving rise to a **multifractal attractor**. In a multifractal attractor, different regions carry different local scaling exponents or fractal dimensions【15†L1179-L1187】【15†L1180-L1183】. This review provides an extensive literature survey of multifractal attractors in dynamical systems, tracing historical breakthroughs, surveying over a hundred key studies and experiments, clarifying the boundary between “fractal” and “multifractal” attractors, and highlighting examples across fluid turbulence, climate, physics, finance, and biology. We also discuss advanced methods for measuring attractor dimensions and multifractal spectra, and outline open problems and future directions. Throughout, we use the term *fractal attractor* to denote an attractor with fractal geometry (often characterized by a single global dimension), and *multifractal attractor* to denote those whose invariant measure has a spectrum of dimensions. 

# Historical Development of Multifractal Attractors  

**Early Chaos and Fractal Geometry (1960s–1970s):** The concept of a strange attractor with fractal structure was first hinted in the 1960s. Edward Lorenz’s seminal 1963 paper on a simple atmospheric model revealed a chaotic attractor with an intricate “butterfly” shape【34†L31-L34】. Lorenz observed sensitive dependence on initial conditions (the “butterfly effect”) and non-repeating trajectories, but the fractal nature of his attractor was only recognized later – its dimension was later estimated to be ~$2.06$【27†L379-L387】.
